docs.lead_paragraph: Lars A. Nyberg, the chairman of the NCR Corporation, is sunk deep into a plush red chair in the ornate music room of Moraine Farm, the luxurious 1920's mansion once owned by Col. Edward A. Deeds, a long-ago chairman of the company that was then known as National Cash Register. It is an oddly luxurious setting in which to discuss Mr. Nyberg's recent cost-cutting.

headline.main: NCR Spreads Its Wings (Flight Insurance, Anyone?)
headline.kicker: Stepping Out of the AT&T Nest

docs.abstract: Lars A Nyberg, chairman of NCR Corp, talks of his plans to return company to financial health before it is spun off from AT&T later this year; NCR lost nearly $4 billion since 1993, two years after AT&T's hostile takeover; Nyberg has cut more than 8,00 jobs in effort to trim $600 million in annual expenses; he has exited the PC business and plans to refocus company on its traditional strengths in automatic teller machines, electronic cash registers and large-scale computers; he faces formidable competition; photos; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: RALPH NADER IS SITTING IN FRONT OF A MIRROR, NOT looking at himself. Fresh from accepting the Presidential nomination of the Green Party U.S.A., he has just finished a very long speech before a very loud crowd, but here in the dingy light of a theater-department dressing room at the University of California at Los Angeles, he gives another, shorter this time. ''I wanted to mimic a Presidential candidate,'' he says. Then he does, meticulously mocking the face, voice and gesture of political cliche: ''My fellow Americans, I stand here before you in the mutual realization that our country is in trouble,'' he intones. ''And if you send me to the White House, I will uphold the trust that you have imposed upon me. . . .'' Within minutes, he is the satirist's Richard Nixon, head trembling, double V's flailing.
docs.abstract: Tish Durkin article on Ralph Nader's campaign for President as the candidate of the Green Party, to which he does not belong; says Nader sees his candidacy as a check on the rightward drift of the Democratic Party, which he believes has become increasingly controlled by business interests under Pres Clinton's leadership; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress directly assaulted welfare programs, it also indirectly launched a piecemeal attack on the intricate set of subsidies built into health, retirement and education programs through which Americans who are financially well off take some responsibility for helping their less fortunate neighbors. In each of these spheres, Americans have typically operated in common pools, with some players paying more so that other, poorer players can pay less. Republican leaders would allow Americans to leave the pools and purchase on their own. Sometimes, breaking the ties of cross-subsidies makes sense because they have become wasteful or unnecessary. In other cases, cross-subsidies must be reshaped as Congress deregulates a market. But what the Republican leaders have in mind is a world in which the Government asks preciously little from people other than to take care of themselves.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that as Congress directly assaulted welfare programs, it also indirectly launched piecemeal attack on intricate set of subsidies built into health, retirement and education programs through which Americans who are financially well off take some responsibility for helping their less fortunate neighbors; maintains that Republican leaders want vouchers that threaten viability of public schools, medical savings accounts that threaten to undermine affordable coverage for chronically ill and Social Security schemes that threaten to bury disproportionate number of elderly in poverty; asserts that these indirect assaults on needy are every bit as pernicious as direct assault on welfare (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The lunchtime crowd had just relieved Lowery's Seafood Restaurant of several hundred fried oysters -- served with salad, two vegetables and tartar or cocktail sauce on the side -- when William Lowery 4th emerged from the kitchen and, despite the distraction of the nearby cash register, tried to focus on the Presidential election. Asked whom he planned to vote for, he hesitated. ''I'll probably vote Republican,'' he replied, finally. ''Always have. That's the way I was brought up.''

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH assistance from the city, a developer has begun building apartments for the low-income elderly in residential neighborhoods, with meals and a modest level of personal services. The rents for the studios and one-bedroom apartments have been kept below $550 a month. Tenant income is limited to $21,500 a year for individuals and $24,600 for couples, which includes Social Security, pension and investment income.

headline.main: Building Apartments for the Low-Income Elderly

docs.lead_paragraph: THE optimism is guarded, but investors in companies specializing in mental health care hope that a new Federal law will bolster the stocks of their somewhat out-of-favor industry. Signed by President Clinton last month, the statute requires employers that offer mental health benefits to be no more restrictive in setting annual or lifetime spending caps on them than the employers are in setting coverage limits for physical health benefits. Currently, many policies pay less for mental than for physical illness. Typical is a $50,000 lifetime limit for mental health benefits and a $750,000 or $1 million limit on physical care. The new law, which applies to companies with more than 50 employees, will take effect in January 1998 and expire in September 2001.

headline.main: Mental Health Ventures May Gain From New Law

docs.abstract: Investors in firms specializing in mental health care are hopeful that new law barring employers who offer mental health benefits from setting more restrictive limits on such benefits than on physical health benefits will bolster industry stocks; law will let companies drop mental health benefits and raise co-payments or deductibles; offers exemption if provision leads to premium rise of over 1 percent; table (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City made a smart move this week when it filed suit against eight tobacco companies and two trade associations to recover billions of dollars spent on medical care for smoking-related illnesses. The lawsuit is justified on public health and fiscal grounds. The suit contends that tobacco use, promoted by the industry through a campaign of deceit and misrepresentation, has jacked up the city's costs for Medicaid, care for the indigent in public hospitals and health-insurance premiums for city workers. By one authoritative estimate, the expense reached $300 million in 1994 alone, or billions over the past several decades. The suit mirrors similar suits filed by 17 states, including Connecticut and New Jersey, and more than a dozen localities.
docs.abstract: Editorial says New York City made smart move when it filed suit against eight tobacco companies and two trade associations to recover billions of dollars spent on medical care for smoking-related illnesses (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Integrated Health Services Inc. has purchased First American Health Care of Georgia Inc. for $154.1 million. Under the accord, First American agreed to pay $255 million to settle charges that it defrauded Medicare. The purchase makes Integrated Health the fourth-largest provider of home health care services in the country. In February, First American and two of its officers were convicted of Medicare fraud in Federal court in Savannah, Ga. Integrated Health could pay as much as an additional $159.1 million for the closely held First American between 2000 and 2004 if First American meets specified financial goals. Integrated Health, based in Owings Mills, Md., operates about 195 offices in 40 states.

headline.main: HOME HEALTH CARE COMPANY BOUGHT FOR $154.1 MILLION
